git init.practical_use: Start a new project tracked by Git

git clone.definition: Clone a repository into a new directory
git clone.practical_use: Download a project from a remote repository like GitHub to work locally

git add.definition: Add files to the staging area
git add.practical_use: Prepare changes for commit by adding modified files to the staging area

git commit.definition: Create a new commit with the changes in the staging area
git commit.practical_use: Save changes to the repository with a descriptive message

git push.definition: Upload local changes to a remote repository
git push.practical_use: Upload local commits to a remote repository, like when contributing to a project on GitHub

git pull.definition: Download changes from a remote repository to your local repository
git pull.practical_use: Update your local repository with the latest changes from the remote

git fetch.definition: Download changes from a remote repository without merging them
git fetch.practical_use: Check the updates from the remote repository without affecting your local work

git branch.practical_use: Manage branches in your repository. Branching is useful when you want to add a feature or fix a bug without disturbing the main code

git merge.definition: Merge changes from one branch into another
git merge.practical_use: Integrate changes from one branch into another, like when you've finished a feature and want to add it to the main code

git diff.definition: Show differences between commits, branches, or files
git diff.practical_use: Review changes you've made in the code

git cherry-pick.definition: Apply a specific commit to the current branch
git cherry-pick.practical_use: Incorporate a specific commit from another branch into the current branch

git status.definition: Show the status of files in the repository
git status.practical_use: Check the current state of files (untracked, modified, staged, etc.) in the repository

git log.practical_use: View the commit history of the repository, including the author, date, and commit message

git rebase.definition: Reapply commits on top of another base commit
git rebase.practical_use: Modify the commit history by moving, combining, or splitting commits

git stash.definition: Save changes that are not ready to be committed
git stash.practical_use: Temporarily save changes without committing them, allowing you to switch branches or perform other tasks

git tag.practical_use: Assign meaningful names to specific points in Git history, such as releases or important commits

git blame.definition: Show who modified each line in a file and when
git blame.practical_use: Identify the author and commit information for each line of a file

git show.definition: Show information about a specific commit
git show.practical_use: Display the details of a commit, including the changes made and the commit message

git revert.definition: Create a new commit that undoes a previous commit
git revert.practical_use: Reverse the changes made by a previous commit and create a new commit to undo those changes

git checkout.practical_use: Switch between branches or restore files to a previous state

git clean.definition: Remove untracked files from the working directory
git clean.practical_use: Delete files that are not tracked by Git, helping to keep the working directory clean

git show-branch.practical_use: Display the commits and their relationships across multiple branches

git archive.definition: Create a tar or zip archive of a repository's contents
git archive.practical_use: Export a specific version of a repository as an archive file for sharing or deployment

git bisect.definition: Find the commit that introduced a bug using binary search
git bisect.practical_use: Systematically identify the commit that introduced a bug by narrowing down the search range

git rebase -i.practical_use: Modify, reorder, squash, or delete commits interactively to refine the commit history

git cherry.definition: Find commits that have not been merged
git cherry.practical_use: Identify commits that exist in one

git add.practical_use: Link a local repository to a remote repository by specifying a remote name and URL

git remove.practical_use: Disconnect a remote repository from the local repository

git rename.practical_use: Change the name of a remote repository in the local repository

git set-url.definition: Change the URL of a remote repository
git set-url.practical_use: Update the URL of a remote repository associated with the local repository

git show.definition: Show information about a remote repository
git show.practical_use: Display details such as the URL and fetch/push configuration of a remote repository

git get-url.definition: Get the URL of a remote repository
git get-url.practical_use: Retrieve the URL of a remote repository associated with the local repository

git prune.definition: Remove stale references to remote branches
git prune.practical_use: Clean up the local repository by removing references to remote branches that no longer exist

git set-head.definition: Set the default branch for fetching from a remote repository
git set-head.practical_use: Configure the default branch to be fetched from a remote repository

git update.practical_use: Fetch the latest changes from the remote repository and update the corresponding remote-tracking branches

git show-tags.definition: Show tags from a remote repository
git show-tags.practical_use: Display the tags available in a remote repository

git prune-tags.definition: Remove tags that no longer exist on the remote repository
git prune-tags.practical_use: Delete local tags that no longer exist in the remote repository

git set-branches.definition: Configure the branches to be pushed to or pulled from a remote repository
git set-branches.practical_use: Specify the branches to be included in push or pull operations with a remote repository

git config --global.definition: Set configuration options globally for all repositories
git config --global.practical_use: Configure Git options that apply to all repositories on the local machine

git config --local.definition: Set configuration options for the current repository
git config --local.practical_use: Configure Git options that apply only to the current repository

git config --user.name.practical_use: Configure the username for the current repository

git config --user.email.definition: Set the email address for Git
git config --user.email.practical_use: Configure the email address for the current repository

git config --list.practical_use: Display a list of all Git configurations for the current repository

git config--global --list.practical_use: Display a list of all global Git configurations for all repositories on the local machine
